tasks.name: plan
tasks.title: Plan the next development task
what to do: Read .project/ docs, README.md, TECHNICAL.md for context.
Use `make help` for commands. Use `uv run` for Python.
Keep database backwards compatible.
Structure: # Plan Next Task ## Analysis ## Solution ## Steps ## Challenges ## Testing

tasks.name: execute
tasks.title: Execute the planned development task
what to do: Read .project/ docs for context. Use `uv run` for Python and `make help` for commands.
Follow the plan. Validate with `make test-all` - no coverage loss or test failures.
Keep database backwards compatible. Update docs (backlog.md, progress.md).
Note any new tasks for backlog.md.

tasks.name: review
tasks.title: Review previous development work
what to do: Review last completed task and changes since last commit.
Validate with `make test-all`. Check docs updated and strategic alignment.
Keep database backwards compatible.
Add new tasks to backlog.md if valuable.

tasks.name: update
tasks.title: Update project status and planning
what to do: Review progress.md and backlog.md current state.
Update both files with completed tasks and metrics.
Unblock dependencies, move ready tasks to active status.

When updating docs (README.md, .project/*, TECHNICAL.md, DEPLOYMENT.md, docs/*), ensure they describe the current architecture and decisions. Remove or compress outdated historical information instead of keeping long change logs there.

tasks.name: commit
tasks.title: Create commits for changes since last commit following git guidelines
what to do: Analyze changes since last commit. Group related changes logically.
Write factual commit messages: <50 char subject, imperative mood, no fluff.
Stage and commit. Don't push.

tasks.name: add-to-backlog
tasks.title: Add a new task to the project backlog
what to do: Read .project/ docs for context.
Analyze task alignment with strategic goals and dependencies.
Add to backlog.md with priority and category recommendation.

tasks.name: execute-backlog-item
tasks.title: Plan and execute a specific backlog item
what to do: Focus on the specified backlog item. Read .project/ docs for context.
Create implementation plan, execute step by step. Use `uv run` for Python.
Test against acceptance criteria. Update docs and mark completed in backlog.md.
Structure: # Execution: [TASK-ID] ## Overview ## Plan ## Steps ## Validation ## Summary

tasks.name: analyze-project
tasks.title: Repository analysis for documentation and backlog management
what to do: Use list_dir and file_search to analyze repository structure.
Check documentation consistency (README.md, .project/*, TECHNICAL.md, DEPLOYMENT.md, docs/*).
For architectural and technical docs, prioritize reflecting the current system state, not history. Remove or rewrite outdated sections instead of appending more history.
Flag any places where historical notes, old plans, or obsolete diagrams make the current architecture unclear. Create backlog items to address these clarity issues.
Identify gaps, outdated references, and backlog management needs. Create tasks for improvements.
Structure: # Analysis ## Documentation Status ## Backlog Needs ## Issues ## Actions

tasks.name: organize-backlog
tasks.title: Organize and clean up project backlog
what to do: Read .project/ docs for context. Make small edits to backlog.md - preserve task IDs.
Remove obsolete tasks, group similar ones, fix dependencies and priorities.
Keep rules at top, details at bottom, use markdown links for navigation.

tasks.name: look-outside-the-box
tasks.title: Generate innovative opportunities
what to do: First, scan plan.md, progress.md, backlog.md, and 'Future Opportunities' in plan.md for existing suggestions. Note any similar ideas already proposed.
Think step-by-step like an innovative strategist: Analyze project docs, code structure, and current capabilities (via list_dir/file_search if needed).

To generate novel ideas, use these techniques: (1) Ask contrarian questions like 'What if we did the opposite?' or 'How could this fail spectacularlyâ€”and turn that into a strength?'; (2) Draw analogies from unrelated industries (e.g., 'How would Netflix/Amazon approach this?'); (3) Brainstorm 8-10 wild, unconventional ideas first, then refine to 2-5 high-impact ones.
For each opportunity, provide: clear value proposition, why it's novel (vs. existing suggestions), and how it expands the project.
Add only new, high-value suggestions to 'Future Opportunities' section in plan.md (not backlog).
Structure: # Innovation ## Step-by-Step Assessment (incl. review of prior suggestions) ## Wild Ideas Brainstorm ## Refined Opportunities ## Value Summary ## Added to plan.md
